The 996 gross ton and 203 feet long steamer headed from New York to the Pacific Coast for Tacoma to Alaska service. Notes: The Edmund Fitzgerald was 729-foot long freighter that sank of an unknown cause in a storm on Lake Superior. The Fitzgerald is the largest ship to sink on the lakes.
The Carl D. Bradley was a Great Lakes freighter that had a 31-year career that suddenly ended in 1958 when she broke in two in a severe November storm on Lake Michigan.
Final disposition: Broke in two in a severe storm on Lake Michigan

Notes: The Daniel J. Morrell was a Great Lakes bulk carrier that sank with only one survivor; 26-year old watchman Dennis Hale of Ashtabula, Ohio.
The William C. Moreland was a Great Lakes bulk carrier that ran aground due to poor visibility on Sawtooth Reef, Lake Superior.
The Cedarville was a self-unloading freighter that sank in the Straits of Mackinac after being rammed by the M/V Topdalsfjord. Ten of the crew drowned when the ship sank.
Final disposition: Sank in the Straits of Mackinac

Notes: The Chester A. Congdon was a steel-hulled bulk carrier that stranded in heavy fog on Canoe Rocks, near Isle Royale.
The D.R. Hanna was a steel-hulled freighter that sank on 16 May 1919 in a collision with the Quincy A. Shaw north of Thunder Bay Island, Lake Huron.
The James C. Carruthers was a 550-foot (170 m) long Canadian freighter that foundered in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913.
Final disposition: Foundered on Lake Huron, in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913

Notes: The Henry B. Smith was an American bulk freighter that foundered in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913 near Marquette, Michigan. Her wreck was discovered in 2013 by a team of divers led by Jerry Eliason.
Final disposition: Sank in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913

Notes: The Emperor was a Canadian freighter owned by Canada Steamship Lines Ltd. that sank after striking the north side of Canoe Rocks near Isle Royale.
Final disposition: Sank after striking the north side of Canoe Rocks

Notes: The Isaac M. Scott was an American bulk carrier that sank on Lake Huron in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913. She was discovered in 1976, laying upside down, and half buried in mud under 180-feet (55m) of water.
Final disposition: Capsized on Lake Huron in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913

Notes: The Charles S. Price capsized on Lake Huron in the Great Lakes Storm of 1913. She was discovered floating upside down near Port Huron.

A 6,100 ton steamer, 436 ft (133 m) in length, with a cargo of 4,700 tons of government stores, allegedly including Harley Davidson motorbikes. Sunk by magnetic parachute mine in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire.[11]

A 6,400 ton steamer, 400 ft (120 m) in length, with a cargo of 1,300 tons of tinplate. Sunk by magnetic parachute mine approx 1-nautical-mile (1.9 km) west of Dale in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire.

Former Bibby Line liner, 7,000 tons, on passage to breakers, lost tow in a storm and ran aground on Cardigan Island; no lives lost, but rats destroyed puffin and Manx shearwater colonies; lies in 12m of water.[12]
A steamship that sank in a storm off the Great Orme.

A 1,218 ton rigged sailing ship, 225 ft (69 m) in length, with a cargo of 7,000 cases of whiskey, beer & general goods. Ran aground at Thorne Island in Milford Haven, Pembrokeshire. Now at a depth of 25 feet (7.6 m), is very broken up, but the brick ballast is still visible.[13]

A brig that struck a reef near Perth.
A barque used for whaling, blown onto a sandbar and subsequently abandoned. The crew survived.[22]
A barque that hit a reef off Rottnest Island with the loss of 11 lives (in the same storm that claimed the Carlisle Castle).[23]
An American barque that struck a reef west of Rat Island in the Houtman Abrolhos. A crew member travelled overland to Fremantle to summon help for the remainder.[24]
A 322-ton barque that dragged its anchor and went ashore at what is now Rockingham.[25][26]
A Portuguese vessel wrecked at Point Cloates[27]
A ship wrecked after hitting a submerged rock off Cape Leeuwin en route to Fremantle.[28]
A River-class destroyer escort that was sunk as an artificial reef.
A 194-ton merchant ship that ran aground at Cottesloe.[29][30]
A vessel blown onto shore near Fremantle (the same storm that wrecked the James).[31]
A 116-ton two-masted wooden-hulled schooner, wrecked near Coral Bay.[32]
A barque that was wrecked at Goode Beach in King George Sound.
A steamship that was wrecked at Calgardup Bay with 12 lives lost.
A 316-ton barque that struck a reef near Beacon Island in the Houtman Abrolhos without loss of life.[33][17]
A barque involved in the guano trade, wrecked without loss of life after striking a reef at Warnbro Sound.[34][35]
A fishing lugger that overturned in strong winds off Gun Island, Houtman Abrolhos, with the loss of 2 of the 3 crew members. The vessel eventually drifted, mastless, onto Wooded Island.[36][37]
A passenger and cargo ship that was blown onto shore from Owen Anchorage, off Fremantle (the same storm that wrecked the Emily Taylor).[38]
A 107-ton former slave ship, which struck rocks and sank near Woodman Point after parting its anchor warp.[39][40]
A barque that went down in a storm off Mandurah.
A fishing boat that ran aground at Pelsaert Island, Houtman Abrolhos.[41][42][36]
A merchant vessel that was bombed by Japanese aircraft and later capsized at Wyndham. The wreck was towed further out to sea in 1948.
A Panamanian bulk carrier that was lost off Cape Cuvier.
A schooner that foundered at Tappers Inlet during a tropical cyclone, without loss of life.[43][44]
German merchant raider scuttled after being damaged in battle by HMAS Sydney.
A steamship wrecked in a storm off Kwinana.
A barque that struck a reef off Rottnest Island.
A barque that sank in Emu Point Channel near Albany
An English whaler wrecked at Mermaid Reef, Rowley Shoals.[47]
A 585-ton barque that was wrecked in a tropical cyclone while collecting guano at the Lacepede Islands.[48]
A sealing vessel that was swept ashore in a gale without any loss of life.[49][50]
A cutter that was wrecked in the Geelvink Channel during a gale, with the loss of one life.[36][51]
A barque that ran aground at Half Moon Reef, Pelsaert Group, Houtman Abrolhos.[52]
A Royal Mail Ship that ran aground off Rockingham.
An ocean liner that struck a rock and sank 6 miles south of Cape Leeuwin.
A Perth-class guided missile destroyer scuttled as a dive wreck off Albany.
A 20-ton schooner that ran aground on Pelsaert Island in the Pelsaert Group of the Houtman Abrolhos without any loss of life.[53][17]
An American China trader wrecked at Ningaloo Reef[54]
Ex- North American. A wooden Clipper abandoned or sunk off Cockburn.[55]
A ship that foundered at Careening Bay, Garden Island.[57]
A bulk carrier that struck a reef off Esperance.
A River-class destroyer escort that was sunk as a dive wreck off Dunsborough.
A Tasmanian-built ketch that struck a submerged rock at Twilight Cove. The crew survived.[58]
Leander class cruiser sunk in battle by the German merchant raider Kormoran.
A ship blown onto shore near Fremantle,[60] during the same storm that wrecked the James and the Emily Taylor.
A River-class destroyer escort that was sunk as a target.
Honourable East India Company ship.
A cutter engaged in transporting materials for the construction of a telegraph line, ran aground at Twilight Cove in a storm that also claimed the Bunyip.[61][62]
A gunboat that was wrecked in the King George Sound.
A schooner that struck a reef in the Pelsaert Group of the Houtman Abrolhos, with the loss of one life. Survivors were stranded on Middle Island for six months.[63][17]
Dutch VOC merchant sailing ship.
A Bathurst-class corvette that collided with the Henry Gilbert Costin off Fremantle.
A brig sunk off Cheynes Beach near Cape Riche
An iron steamer wrecked on Half Moon Reef, Pelsaert Group, Houtman Abrolhos with the loss of 3 lives, plus a further 2 rescuers. It had been en route from Fremantle to Hong Kong.[64]
A steamship that sank off Gregory.
A schooner that hit Scott Reef during a gale.[65]
Dutch VOC merchant sailing ship.
Dutch VOC merchant sailing ship.
